docs.lead_paragraph: In this week's New York Times Magazine, Gary Taubes, author most recently of "Why We Get Fat: And What to Do About It," takes on sugar. Among other things, he writes about the views of Robert Lustig, an obesity expert at the University of California, San Francisco, School of Medicine.

headline.main: Talk to Gary Taubes About Sugar

docs.abstract: Health writer Gary Taubes responds to reader questions about sugar and why we get fat.
docs.snippet: Health writer Gary Taubes responds to reader questions about sugar and why we get fat.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the scheme of things, saving the 38 billion bucks that Congress seems poised to agree upon is not a big deal. A big deal is saving a trillion bucks. And we could do that by preventing disease instead of treating it.

headline.main: How to Save a Trillion Dollars

docs.abstract: As Congress tries to get the budget under control, it's worth noting the fiscal toll of treating "lifestyle diseases."
docs.snippet: As Congress tries to get the budget under control, it's worth noting the fiscal toll of treating "lifestyle diseases."

docs.lead_paragraph: At the end of life, people with chronic diseases get more aggressive care in the New York area than anyplace else in the country, a new report says.

docs.lead_paragraph: The more I talk to researchers about caring for older people, the more a couple of themes emerge. Namely:

headline.main: For Elderly Diabetics, Questions About Aggressive Care

docs.abstract: Aggressive control of blood sugar levels makes little sense for frail, elderly patients with Type 2 diabetes, one researcher maintains.
docs.snippet: Aggressive control of blood sugar levels makes little sense for frail, elderly patients with Type 2 diabetes, one researcher maintains.

docs.lead_paragraph: STRAUS--Dr. Eugene. Physician, teacher, researcher and author passed away after a long illness on April 2 in NYC. He was a Renaissance man who was Chief of Digestive Diseases at the State University of New York Health Science Center, co-chair of Dept. of Medicine and director of the largest Digestive Disease training program in the country. A gastroenterologist by training, he had a brilliant career as a biomedical researcher developing a unique test for TB used around the world. Working with Sol Berson and Rosalyn Yalow, the first woman to win a Nobel Prize in Medicine, they developed revolutionary new techniques in radioimmunoassay. Straus taught at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and other Medical Centers in NYC, co-chaired Dept. of Clinical Sciences at Montefiore with Yalow, was an Honorary member of the Endocrine Society and recently honored by SUNY Downstate for his life's work in Medicine. He published 150 medical research papers and two books, Rosalyn Yalow/Nobel Laureate & Medical Marvels, written with his son Alex Straus and illus. by Bette Korman. He is survived by his wife of 20 years Bette Korman/founder Children's Museum of Manhattan, his son Alex Straus, daughter's Sylvie StrausFigueroa and Allegra Sherrod, stepdaughter Radha Korman, six grandchildren and sister Ruth Gainer. He will be missed and mourned by all.
docs.snippet: STRAUS--Dr. Eugene. Physician, teacher, researcher and author passed away after a long illness on April 2 in NYC. He was a Renaissance man who was Chief of Digestive Diseases at the State University of New York Health Science Center, co-chair of...
